acdc.Core

Class RecursiveCreateTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinTask<V>
      • java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<File1>
        • acdc.Core.RecursiveCreateTree
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.util.concurrent.Future<File1>

    public class RecursiveCreateTree
extends java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<File1>
    RecursiveCreateTree is the class allowing you to get a tree.

    It uses the Fork/Join Framework to split the work. It extends from RecursiveTask that allows to return a result. I use it to return the build tree. For each folder, a class is instantiated. You can choose the level of parallelism you want (how many worker threads to use).

    To walk the file system tree, it uses WalkFileTree from Files. When an IOException occurs, it adds the error message in the ErrorLogging class.

    When Files.walkFileTree visit files, it uses the filter to add only the matching files.

    During Files.walkFileTree, it adds the file size and adds it to the parent folder recursively.

    Since it's in multithread with multiple instance of WalkFileTree, the maxDepth coming with WalkFileTree doesn't work. So, I use the pathNameCount of the current dir and I compare it to the original path requested. With this, I join the folders and add the files only if the current depth is smaller than the max depth. But I continue creating instances of RecursiveCreateTree in preVisitDirectory() in order to get the size of the folders of the tree even when I passed the maxDepth.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Baptiste
